#Text=Another artifact that may be observed in certain rear projection screens is speckle.
#Text=Speckle is observed as randomly oriented patterns that appear to move with the slight movement of the eye.
#Text=Speckle relates generally to coherent interference and is more typically observed when screens are used with high magnification systems in which the projected beam is nearly coherent.
#Text=Destroying the coherence of the illumination beam may reduce speckle.
#Text=For example, speckle can be reduced or eliminated by increasing the amount of diffusion and/or the thickness of the diffuser.
#Text=As described more fully below, increasing the thickness of a diffuser to reduce or eliminate color and speckle may have the disadvantage of decreasing the screen resolution and gain.
#Text=Color and speckle artifacts on a screen are often collectively observed as scintillation.
#Text=In general, color and speckle follow the same trend (e.g., speckle reduces as the amount of color is reduced).
#Text=One way to quantify scintillation is to measure the brightness uniformity on a pixel size level.
#Text=The non-uniformity resulting from scintillation can be expressed in terms of the standard deviation.
#Text=The presence of scintillation can also be expressed qualitatively.
#Text=Qualitative evaluation is important since the eye is able to efficiently detect scintillation.

#Text=As noted above, the resolution of the rear projection screen is becoming more important as rear projection display applications require screens with increasingly higher resolution.
#Text=The resolution of a screen is generally defined as a measure of the finest detail that can be distinguished in an image projected on the screen.

#Text=One method of measuring resolution is accomplished by projecting an image on the screen representing a series of sets of dark and bright lines at progressively smaller spacing to ascertain the limiting number of lines per millimeter that can be resolved.
#Text=Using this method the resolution of the screen can be quantified as the ability to resolve horizontal and/or vertical bars at different spatial frequencies.
#Text=Screen resolution can be quantified by measuring the modulation depth (MD) depth of the screen in the manner depicted in FIGS. 2A and 2B.
#Text=As illustrated in FIG. 2A, the modulation depth is measured by examining a pattern 201 of repeating bright 205 and dark 207 images transmitted through the screen.
#Text=The pattern 201 is scanned along a line 203 orthogonal to the bars.
#Text=The scan measures the intensity of light as a function of position along the scan line 203.
#Text=The results of such a scan can be graphically represented by plotting the intensity as a function of position along the scan line 203 as illustrated in FIG. 2B.
#Text=The scanned intensities can be used to calculate an intercharacter contrast (ICC) value.
